item.title: Cronos: The New Dawn Review‚ÄîA New Harbinger Of Horror Has Merged
item.content:encoded:
Bloober Team is hot off the heels of its 2024 success. Cronos: The New Dawn is a brand-new IP from the makers of the Silent Hill 2 Remake, and it has everything you could want from a survival-horror game: A nervous atmosphere, a constant feeling of trepidation and jeopardy, grotesque monsters, and an inventory so limited you‚Äôre wondering if you can stuff a few more ammo clips into your suit.

Cronos: The New Dawn feels safe‚Äîand I hate using that word with new games, as it feels like an insult. It feels like a pejorative, but in many cases (this one especially) it‚Äôs a compliment. Bloober Team throws out the odd new idea here and there, but the game feels like a well-rounded survival horror title with an interesting story.

The game‚Äôs central enemy mechanic revolves around the concept of merging, and it feels like Cronos has dipped its hand into the best pots, aptly creating an amalgamation of tried and tested horror tropes to produce a polished and impactful debut.

Cronos: The New Dawn Review

You are a nameless Traveler: A mysterious figure sent to retrieve items, uncover time rifts to gain a deeper understanding of the planet‚Äôs implosion, and explore its fallen remnants in search of The Traveler who came before you. The ‚ÄòChange‚Äô brought the world to its knees and executed it in cold-hearted fashion. All that remains is a series of monsters‚Äîeach more unpleasant than the last‚Äîwho merge with defeated enemies and become stronger‚Äîwhich is a real problem for you!

I found the first hour of Cronos: The New Dawn to be a bit slow and unengaging, to be honest. You think of Silent Hill 2‚Äôs foggy and genuinely haunting opening moments, whereas Dead Space hits you with loud, blaring danger sirens as a Necromorph tries to pierce you in a tense elevator chase sequence. Any lingering doubts quickly evaporated into intrigue as the story and gameplay improved progressively. It crescendoed by the end of my 14 hours in Cronos‚Äô hellscape, and I was truly left wanting more when the credits rolled.

The story feels a bit ambiguous and ambitious for its scope at times, but the final payoff is satisfying. It probably requires a second playthrough to fully grasp the intricacies of the narrative‚Äôs details, which are revealed through cutscenes and typical world-building notes and tapes scattered throughout the game‚Äôs various vile and decrepit biomes.

Don‚Äôt Fix What Isn‚Äôt broken

If you‚Äôve played any survival-horror game before, Cronos swiftly becomes second-nature. You need to be accurate, and learning the game‚Äôs charge-up mechanic is crucial to make shots stronger and optimize ammo management. The upgrade system is a slow-burner (don‚Äôt expect to upgrade even half your gear by the time your first playthrough is done), and the pacing ducks and dives between combat-heavy encounters and exploration.

The game genuinely improves as it unfolds, allowing you to acquire more weapons and tools. I would‚Äôve liked more variety in the weaponry, but your flame Tool and explosive bombs you get somewhat compensate. Cronos‚Äô level designs range from snowy exteriors to dank, dilapidated residential buildings with monsters scuttling around every surface. You risk eternal dizziness as you need to have your head on a swivel, lest you get pounced on by an unsuspecting enemy.

My favorite portion of Cronos was a hospital section midway through the game‚Äîno prizes for where the inspiration came from here. Puzzles aren‚Äôt really at the forefront of Cronos‚Äô design, but this area requires multiple keys, and special items are necessary for doors and hidden areas. The tension was palpable throughout, too. My anxiety and nervousness were through the roof as I ventured into unknown corridors and rooms, and there wasn‚Äôt enough absorption in the world to mop up my terror sweats.

Cronos has jump scares aplenty, and its addictive 80s synth music offsets any built-up paranoia you‚Äôre likely to experience. As much as you won‚Äôt want to, searching the vicinity is a must. Despite being advertised as a hard game, I comfortably finished Cronos with under 10 deaths‚Äîbut I am well-versed in the genre. Seek out Energy, look for Cores, and your cat-like curiosity will be rewarded‚Äîthere are literally cat collectibles.

If you‚Äôre worried there‚Äôs not enough of a challenge, a Hard Mode is unlocked at the end, along with a New Game+ setting.

Room For One More, Please?

I‚Äôll flat-out say Cronos‚Äô inventory system is frustrating beyond belief. It‚Äôs probably the most oppressive balancing act since Resident Evil 0. If you don‚Äôt focus your Core upgrades on increasing your inventory slots ASAP, you‚Äôre going to suffer. Each ammo slot doesn‚Äôt hold much, and you can never truly have a consistent balance of ammunition, weapons, and health.

If you find a health item out in the open, you can‚Äôt use it; it has to be in your inventory. The only way to drop items is to permanently discard them. You‚Äôre telling me we can have magical inventory boxes that can transfer your gear from one safe area to the next, but I can‚Äôt use a first aid pickup right in front of me?

You often have compulsory story items taking up slots, and I ended up not really using the game‚Äôs central burning mechanic because each flame canister‚Äîyou guessed it‚Äîtakes up an inventory slot. I felt punished for minimizing ammo and resource waste. Now, I think the game‚Äôs Hard Mode will be better-suited for me, and inexperienced horror fans are probably going to chew through supplies faster than a hungry mouse does a block of cheese, but veterans might get the ick from the system‚Äôs obtrusiveness.

Cronos: The New Dawn Verdict

The critic in me will say Cronos: The New Dawn isn‚Äôt transcendent. Again, this is ok. What Cronos does, it does very well, and taking the recency bias of the Silent Hill 2 Remake out of the equation, I can‚Äôt recall a new survival-horror game I‚Äôve enjoyed this much and found this immersive in a while.

Once it gets going, Cronos batters you with a buffet of scares, stress, and superb combat. I can‚Äôt overlook the stingy inventory management headaches that will last a lifetime, but there‚Äôs no denying that Cronos: The New Dawn wants you to think and strategize. I‚Äôll wrap up this review by saying Cronos: the New Dawn is an excellent new survival-horror title. If you have an interest in the genre, this is a must-play, and old-school horror fans will love this: Such is our calling.

4 ‚Äì Great

The Insider Gaming forum is the usual go-to for all your thoughts on gaming. I‚Äôd also recommend you check out some of IG‚Äôs other recent reviews: Killing Floor 3, Wuchang: Fallen Feathers, Madden 26, and Dead Take.

NOTE: A copy of Cronos: The New Dawn on PS5 was provided to Insider Gaming for the purposes of this review.

item.title: Sonic Racing CrossWorlds Won‚Äôt Be Influenced By Mario Kart World
item.content:encoded:
The Sonic Series Producer has stated that Mario Kart World did not influence Sonic Racing CrossWorlds in any way.

Sonic Racing CrossWorlds launches this month on September 25, 2025. Ahead of the release, players will be able to try the game through an open network test scheduled for mid-September. Ahead of that, the developers have revealed how Mario Kart World had no impact on their upcoming title‚Äôs development plans.

Mario Kart World Did Not Influence Sonic Racing CrossWorlds Development Plans

During an interview with Traxion (via MyNintendoNews), Sonic Series Producer Takashi Iizuka spoke about Mario Kart World‚Äôs impact on Sonic Racing CrossWorlds. Izuka first stated that, like everyone, they are also unaware of the ‚Äúroad map of Mario Kart titles‚Äù and were ‚Äúsurprised‚Äù when it was released. At the same time, the developers were expecting one to be released soon, as Nintendo ‚Äútypically‚Äù releases a new karting title with new hardware.

However, Iizuka added, ‚ÄúWhether or not Mario Kart was going to be released, our goal was to develop the best kind of Sonic racing title. That hasn‚Äôt changed ‚Äì Mario Kart World won‚Äôt have any influence.‚Äù Izuka also spoke about the differences between the two games, which include cross-play, a customizable gadget system, characters from other IPs, Travel Rings, and more.

He stated that these features add ‚Äúdepth to the racing and are something other kart racers aren‚Äôt doing.‚Äù Izuka concluded, saying, ‚ÄúEven though Mario Kart World was announced, it didn‚Äôt influence our development plans.‚Äù

In other news, Sonic Racing CrossWorlds‚Äô complete character list has been revealed, including launch, season pass, and bonus characters. What are your thoughts on Mario Kart World not influencing Sonic Racing CrossWorlds? Let us know through the official Insider Gaming forums discussion.

item.title: 007 First Light Collector‚Äôs Edition Will Set You Back $300
item.content:encoded:
007 First Light‚Äôs price details have surfaced online for the standard and collector‚Äôs editions.

PlayStation is all set to host an exclusive State of Play event for 007 First Light today, featuring 30 minutes of gameplay around Bond‚Äôs first mission as an MI6 Recruit. Ahead of the showcase, a reliable source has already provided price details about IO Interactive‚Äôs upcoming title.

007 First Light Price Details Revealed

The price information for 007 First Light comes from billbil-kun‚Äôs latest post on X (formerly Twitter). The post states that the upcoming title will be available in both physical and collector‚Äôs editions. The Standard Edition of 007 First Light has been priced at USD $69.99 for the PlayStation 5, Xbox Series X/S, and Switch 2. The Collector‚Äôs Edition will be priced at $300, and the listings for the PlayStation 5, Xbox Series X, and PC versions are already live on Amazon.

For those unaware, 007 First Light is an upcoming single-player action adventure by IO Interactive, where players step into the shoes of a young James Bond and explore his origin story of becoming the world‚Äôs most famous spy. It is a cinematic experience that will have players exploring breathtaking locations, driving various vehicles, fighting using their fists and firepower, as well as using gadgets to infiltrate and spy.

In other news, the developers of 007 First Light have revealed how Hitman was an influence on the game. Additionally, the upcoming game is more of a spy thriller than an action shooter.
